headline: EADS-BAE Deal Hits Snag
summary: Efforts to win approval for the merger of Airbus parent EADS and Britain's BAE Systems are focusing on Berlin, where politicians are voicing strong reservations.

headline: Shelling Out for Cocktails
summary: Sweet meets spicy in the Leadbelly's revelatory drink, the Spicey Pineapple.

headline: Here's a Sport Where Players Get to Do the Wave
summary: Once a year, the low tide allows a cricket match to be played on a sandbar off England's coast.

headline: Playing Cricket at Sea
summary: For about an hour each year, the tide usually drops low enough to expose a small triangle of sand in the English Channel. This sticky wicket, in the middle of a hectic shipping lane, is the scene for the annual Brambles cricket match.

headline: Christie Fends Off Right
summary: An obscure Christie administration regional planning document has fueled opposition among a faction of the state's staunchest conservatives who said the proposal usurps property rights.

headline: CAW Reaches Labor Deal With Chrysler
summary: The Canadian Auto Workers union said it has reached a new tentative labor contract with Chrysler, the last of the three Detroit auto makers to sign a deal that secures labor peace for four more years.

headline: Humans in Control
summary: Ralph Gardner Jr. joined animal-control expert Mike Pastore from Animal Care & Control on a recent afternoon as he responded to a report of a confined stray dog in the Bronx.

headline: Hospital's Ex-CEO Charged in Schemes
summary: The former chief executive of the Hospital for Special Surgery on the Upper East Side was charged with collecting $1.4 million from three kickback schemes he allegedly engineered while at the helm of the oldest U.S. orthopedic hospital.

headline: Son Questioned in Death
summary: Police were questioning a 16-year-old Bronx boy in the fatal shooting of his mother, whose body was placed inside a plastic bin that was discarded outside their home, a law-enforcement official said.

headline: MTA Ad Policy Faces Overhaul
summary: The MTA will begin an internal debate on its advertising policies, just more than two months after its refusal of an anti-Muslim ad campaign was ruled to have violated the First Amendment of the Constitution.

headline: Harvard Tries to Catch Yale
summary: The Yale Club of New York has long had a dining space and terrace on its 22nd floor, giving members a sky view of the city. Now the Harvard Club of New York City plans to catch up, hoping to add a bar and terrace to its rooftop.

headline: Capturing a Golden Anniversary on Film
summary: With more than 160 films divvied up among its main slate and multiple sidebars, the New York Film Festival is going big for its 50th annual edition.

headline: Venezuela Election Fuss: Polling Gaps
summary: Venezuelan polling firms are painting starkly different pictures of the coming presidential election in which President Chávez faces a tough re-election campaign, raising questions about the credibility of some polling firms.

headline: Bradshaw Is Back in Action for the Giants
summary: Running back Ahmad Bradshaw practiced Wednesday for the first time since injuring his neck in Week 2 and will start Sunday night at Philadelphia.

headline: U.S. Ties Libya Attack to 'Powder Keg' in Mali
summary: Mali has become an incubator for terrorist activity that demands urgent international attention, world leaders said Wednesday.

headline: The Jets: A Replacement Writer's Take
summary: What if our Jets scribe followed the NFL's lead and let a replacement reporter cover practice?

headline: An Uptown Treasure Trove
summary: In the former stables of the townhouse owned by architect Grosvenor Atterbury, Monday, Jamie Creel and Christopher Gow are opening a new decorative arts store for gifts and conversation pieces.

headline: Playing Ball in Brooklyn Arts
summary: Mikhail Prokhorov and his sister have made a $1 million grant to the Brooklyn Academy of Music through the Mikhail Prokhorov Fund.

headline: Google's Brazil Chief Detained
summary: Brazil's police briefly detained the head of Google Inc.'s local operations after the company failed to act on a judge's order to remove videos criticizing a politician from its YouTube site.

headline: The CEOs Behind Air-Deal Talks
summary: A combination of EADS and BAE would bring together two different aviation businesses led by two equally different chief executives: Tom Enders and Ian King.

headline: Big Firms Overhaul Health Coverage
summary: Sears Holdings and Darden Restaurants are planning a radical change in the way they provide health benefits to their workers, giving employees a fixed sum of money and allowing them to choose their medical coverage and insurer from an online marketplace.

headline: How to Catch a Stray
summary: Columnist Ralph Gardner learns how to capture a dog on a trip with an animal-control expert from Animal Care & Control.

headline: Asia in Pictures
summary: A woman walks out of the Sule Pagoda in Yangon, policewomen hit a student protester with batons in India, a boy uses a plastic bag as a kite in Afghanistan, and more.

headline: New-Home Sales Fall, but Prices Jump
summary: Sales of newly built homes in the U.S. fell slightly 0.3% August, but prices posted their largest gains since late 2004.

headline: Choosing Shoes With Joie de Vivre
summary: How Paris-based designer Pierre Hardy avoids falling into a shoe rut.

headline: Trouble in Quartzsite, Ariz.
summary: This tiny desert outpost is known for 70-degree winters, an annual gem show that draws millions of visitors, and a bookstore owner who conducts business in little more than flip-flops and a straw hat.

headline: Scandals Rain on Berlusconi's Party
summary: A rash of scandals is draining support from former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi's political party ahead of elections in Italy, threatening to drive voters to antieuro populist parties.

headline: EPA Says Wyoming Fracking Results Are Consistent
summary: The EPA said new government tests of groundwater near Pavillion, Wyo., have yielded results similar to data it released last year, when it suggested chemicals in the water were linked to hydraulic fracturing.

headline: Foreigners Move In on Chinese Stocks
summary: Chinese shares fell to their lowest intraday level in nearly four years on Wednesday, and some foreign fund managers say they are ready to pounce.

headline: Spain Scare Roils Markets
summary: Spain's prospects of avoiding a government bailout appeared to recede as pessimism pervaded the country's financial markets and pushed its borrowing costs higher.

headline: RIM Courts App Makers
summary: BlackBerry maker RIM touted partnerships with Twitter and Facebook as the struggling company prepares to report its second quarter earnings.

headline: Credit Suisse May Revamp Asset-Management Unit
summary: Credit Suisse is considering restructuring its asset-management unit in order to save costs.

headline: Ex-Credit Suisse Banker Arrested
summary: U.K. authorities arrested a former Credit Suisse banker on U.S. allegations that he conspired to inflate the values of mortgage bonds during the financial crisis.

headline: Oil Futures Drop, Gas Rises After Explosion
summary: U.S. gasoline futures jumped 3.8% while crude-oil prices declined, after an explosion at a major refinery in Canada focused attention on low U.S. fuel supplies.

headline: Wool Crafts a Comeback
summary: Global production of wool is at the lowest level in more than 70 years. Sheep growers around the world have thinned herds and directed resources to other commodities, such as meat and grains. Now, an industry group is trying to change that.

headline: Romney Tempers Tax Plans
summary: Mitt Romney, seeking to emphasize his deficit-cutting ambitions, is warning Americans that his tax-cut plan might not decrease their tax bills as much as they expect.

headline: Small-Town Politics, All-Out War
summary: The tiny desert outpost of Quartzsite, Ariz., is known for its 70-degree winters and annual gem show that draws thousands of visitors. The latest claim to fame is its crazy local politics.

headline: Making the 'Pharmacy Crawl'
summary: A clampdown by at least eight states on abuse of painkiller pills has left some legitimate patients traveling from drugstore to drugstore to get their prescriptions filled.

headline: Blasts Hit Syria Military Headquarters
summary: Two large explosions hit Syria's military headquarters in Damascus, the latest in a string of attacks against state facilities.

headline: Need a Loan? Where Do You Live?
summary: The long-awaited recovery in bank lending to consumers is under way in some smaller cities but remains depressed in large metropolitan areas on the coasts.

headline: The Social-Enterprise Approach to Job Creation
summary: Helping people stay in school, out of prison and off the government dole.

headline: California City May Declare Fiscal Emergency
summary: Atwater, a city in California's Central Valley, may declare a fiscal emergency as soon as next week, but is trying to avoid becoming the fourth city in the state to file for municipal bankruptcy this year.

headline: Inside Assad's Killing Fields
summary: The bomb from the Syrian jet exploded, sending rubble and dust pouring into the hospital reception area.

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: An excerpt from the 2009 memoir "Moon River and Me" by singer Andy Williams, who died Sept. 26 at age 84.

headline: Sean Fieler: Easy Money Is Punishing the Middle Class
summary: A policy of low but persistent inflation anesthetizes workers to declining real wages.

headline: Rove: Obama's Biggest Opponent Is the Truth
summary: Voters expect Mitt Romney to blow the whistle in the debates.

headline: Fiat Asks Court to Set Chrysler Value
summary: Italian auto maker Fiat said it asked a U.S. court to resolve a dispute over the price it must pay a retiree health care trust for shares in Chrysler after the two sides differed on terms of a contract.

headline: Consumer Rebound Built on Solid Foundations
summary: It was housing that left the U.S. economy in shambles. Now it may be housing that is keeping it from buckling.

headline: Wisconsin's Judicial Recall
summary: Unions want liberal judges to overturn Scott Walker's reforms.

headline: Lexus Rules Out Run for Luxury Crown
summary: A Lexus executive ruled out the brand's run for the title of best-selling U.S. luxury car this year after losing the title a year ago and falling to third place behind BMW and Mercedes.

headline: What's in Your Mobile Wallet? Not Much
summary: Banks, merchants and tech companies have bet billions of dollars on mobile-payment systems, but a number of hurdles are squelching widespread adoption.

summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: Bringing the Ice-Cream Truck Back Into Baseball
summary: Should this season's wild-card winners dial down the party? Jason Gay thinks it's obvious how they should celebrate: Summon the ice-cream truck.

headline: Style for an Older Bride
summary: Columnist Teri Agins answers a 71-year-old reader's question about what to wear for her wedding.

headline: O'Grady: How Canada Saved Its Bacon
summary: Deep cuts in government spending pulled Canada back from an epic fiscal crisis in the 1990s.

headline: SEC Looks for 'Kill' Switches
summary: U.S. regulators have launched a sweeping review of the systems brokerages and trading firms use to place orders, including how firms can override their automated computer systems and turn them off.

headline: The Heart and Soul of Dixieland
summary: A new boxed set celebrates 50 years of New Orleans's Preservation Hall Jazz Band.

headline: Hidden in the Valley
summary: The Arkell Museum at Canajoharie represents an improbable bounty of works by great American artists, tucked away in upstate New York.

headline: Schapiro Lieutenants Depart From SEC
summary: In recent months, several senior officials have left the SEC or the chairman's office, which has fueled speculation that Schapiro could step down as well.

headline: Strong Debut for Santander's Mexican Unit
summary: Shares of Banco Santander's Mexican unit climbed in both New York and Mexico City, in what was the biggest listing to hit U.S. exchanges since Facebook in May.

headline: Stocks Fall For 3rd Straight Day
summary: Energy and technology shares pulled stocks lower, as well as disappointing U.S. housing data and signs of increasing instability in the euro zone.

headline: Dish Adds a Broadband Service
summary: Dish Network is adding a satellite broadband service called dishNET that will  target rural customers with little or no current Internet access.

headline: Canadian Dollar Weighed By Worries About Europe
summary: Worries about Europe's debt crisis weigh on market psyche, dragging the Canadian dollar to three-week lows against the safe-haven U.S. dollar.

headline: Silver's Strength Looks Set to Continue
summary: Market Focus: Central-bank stimulus moves have helped drive silver prices up sharply in the past two months, and analysts say the metal looks poised to continue its climb until the end 2013.

headline: CORRECTIONS
summary: Canada's Liberal Party won reelection in 1997 and again in 2000, when it also increased its majority. The Sept. 24 Americas column misstated the results of the 1997 election. Steve Kroft of CBS News interviewed President Obama for "60 Minutes." The Sept. 25 editorial, "The 10% President," misspelled his name.

headline: New Labor Attitudes Fed Into China Riot
summary: Workers at China's huge Foxconn factory said tensions over strict rules helped spur this week's rioting, in events that raise questions about the sustainability of China's manufacturing machine.

headline: Each State Must Take Responsibility
summary: I don't believe it is possible to read your editorial "An Illinois Pension Bailout?" (Sept. 21) without screaming: "No taxation without representation!"

headline: Exploring the World And One's Navel, Too
summary: It seems to me that "Walking the Amazon" by Ed Stafford (Bookshelf, Sept. 17) is an elaborate metaphor for human activity in general and political nonsense in particular.

headline: 'Soft' Employment Skills and Virtue as Job Qualifiers
summary: Regarding Nick Schulz's "Hard Unemployment Truths About 'Soft' Skills" (op-ed, Sept. 20): I own and operate an employment service which has worked with dozens of small businesses in the past 15 years. We have jobs going begging for exactly the reasons mentioned by Mr. Schulz.

headline: The White House and Free Speech
summary: Gordon Crovitz's criticism ("The White House Goes Mum on Free Speech," Information Age, Sept. 24) of the administration's supposed advocacy of "censorship" in response to the "Innocence of Muslims" confuses two concepts.

headline: AARP, ObamaCare and Future Health Care for Seniors
summary: Kimberley Strassel's "The Love Song of AARP and Obama" (Potomac Watch, Sept. 21) is an unfortunate compilation of rehashed attacks against AARP, made particularly disappointing because of our effort to work with the author to address the flawed arguments. We appreciate the opportunity to correct the record.

headline: 'Smart City' Planning Needs Balance
summary: Ben Rooney: By harvesting data that people generate as they traverse a city, planners can optimize services to make them efficient. But such programs could threaten the vitality that attract people in the first place.

headline: Senior Auditor Departs National Futures Association
summary: The director of audits and investigations for the National Futures Association has departed, as the derivatives industry's self-regulatory body seeks to tighten oversight of firms and assume oversight of the huge swaps trading market.

headline: TPG Founder Upbeat on China, Not on Japan
summary: David Bonderman, co-founder of private-equity firm TPG, sees starkly differing prospects for his industry in Asia, from fast-growing China, where he says prices look attractive, to Japan, where finding desirable deals remains tough.

headline: RadioShack CEO Out After a Year
summary: RadioShack Chief Executive James Gooch is leaving the consumer-electronics retailer, after little more than a year on the job, amid a mutual agreement with the board.

headline: Stock Exodus Goes On, But Bond Funds Fatten
summary: Long-term mutual funds increased by $4.47 billion in the latest week as hybrid and bond funds continued to post inflows, offsetting accelerating declines in equity funds.

headline: Emerging-Market Currencies Edge Lower
summary: Emerging-market currencies took a turn downward as investors booked profit on recent gains, and developments in Europe stoked anxiety about the euro-zone debt crisis.

headline: Mid-Market Street, as Seen by One of Its Own
summary: Mark Ellinger, a photographer and historian of mid-Market Street and the Tenderloin, discusses recent changes in the central San Francisco neighborhood.

headline: Brazil's Real Closes Weaker
summary: Brazil's real weakened against the dollar as market participants turned their attention to international markets and to the setting of the Ptax, a local monthly reference rate.

headline: Treasurys Notch Eighth Day of Gains
summary: A flight for safety boosted prices of U.S. Treasury bonds for an eighth straight session, the longest winning streak since December 2008.

headline: Photos of the Day: Sept. 26
summary: In today's photos, fiery protests erupt in Athens, a farmer makes his own prostheses in China, another version of the 'Mona Lisa' is displayed in Geneva, and more.

headline: Hotaru
summary: Long before sushi went mainstream, Japanese-food lovers made San Mateo a destination. Hotaru, located on a busy downtown drag, is a fixture of the scene.

headline: Vital Signs
summary: Overseas investors put $685 million into commercial real estate in San Francisco during the second quarter, making the city second only to New York in attracting foreign capital to real estate, data show.

headline: Dress Codes
summary: The Ivy League look is the closest this country comes to a style deemed aristocratic. Get it wrong and you're locked out of the tribe.

headline: Dean Foods Explores Sale of a Second Unit
summary: Dean Foods is exploring a sale of its Morningstar dairy business, the smallest of its three segments. The move indicates a greatly slimmed down company, as Dean already is looking to spin off another unit.

headline: Corn, Soybeans Settle at 12-Week Lows
summary: Corn prices, which soared to record highs in August, are stumbling as U.S. farmers harvest their crops at a record pace, accentuating a seasonal rise in supplies that happens this time of year.

headline: Gas: Coal's Worst Frenemy
summary: You know things are bad when you start rooting for the enemy. For coal miners, it's that bad.

headline: Gas Prices Soar After Refinery Blast
summary: U.S. gasoline futures jumped 3.8% while crude-oil prices declined, settling below $90 a barrel, after an explosion at a major refinery in Canada focused attention on low U.S. fuel supplies.

headline: What's News
summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Asia.

headline: Japan, China Ministers Meet in New York
summary: Jaoan's Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda addressed the territorial disputes simmering between Japan and its Asian neighbors in a speech at the United Nations, a day after a meeting between the foreign ministers of Japan and China.

headline: Need a Ride? Find One With Your Smartphone
summary: Many Silicon Valley tech-savvy residents no longer hail taxis, opting instead to find a ride by tapping on one of the geo-located mobile apps that have cropped up in the past couple of years.

headline: Alberto Gallo: The Curious Case of the Euro Zone
summary: Europe must move quickly to improve bank capital and stop deposit flight. Otherwise, its clock will continue to tick backward.

headline: Key Goal Delayed at Hunters View
summary: In Hunters Point, one of San Francisco's poorest neighborhoods, construction is moving along on three new residential buildings and a park, but a critical element of the effort has stalled.

headline: Gold Eases on Europe Concerns
summary: Gold settled 0.7% lower, pressured by a rise in the U.S. dollar because of escalating tension in Europe's financial markets.

headline: Who Should Pay Spain's Crisis Costs?
summary: Even as the euro-zone fights to unite at a national level, the strains of the crisis are showing up further down the political chain. In Spain, Catalonia illustrates the struggle over who should pay the costs of the financial crisis.

headline: EU Lawmakers Call for Delay on Trades
summary: European lawmakers want trading venues and exchanges to impose a minimum half-second delay on executing orders in a bid to temper excessive market volatility.

headline: Coffee Mavens' Perfect Roast Starts at Home
summary: Some Bay Area residents are going to great lengths to get the perfect cup of coffee, acquiring raw beans and roasting them at home before grinding and brewing.

headline: GOP Fight for Senate Hits Snags
summary: A surprisingly close contest in Indiana adds to the challenges for a party once considered likely to regain a Senate majority.

headline: U.K. Party Chief Urges Remaining in Coalition
summary: British Deputy Prime Minister Nick Clegg urged followers of his embattled Liberal Democrat party to support the government coalition in which it plays the role of junior partner, despite painful spending cuts.

headline: Bumi Resources Responds to Probe
summary: Bumi Resources offered its first official response to news that key shareholder Bumi PLC is investigating possible financial and other irregularities at its Indonesian operations.

headline: Renault, Hyundai Add to Gloom
summary: Renault and Hyundai said the European car market is contracting faster than they had expected, adding to the gloom that threatens to overshadow this week's glitzy Paris motor show.

headline: Sudans Summit Extended to Friday
summary: The presidents of Sudan and South Sudan failed to reach an agreement on cross-border security after three days of talks in Ethiopia. The summit is expected to continue Friday amid looming U.N. sanctions.

headline: A Hangout for All Your Social-Network Photos
summary: Katherine Boehret tests ThisLife, a service that pulls in photos and videos from various social networks, and Seagate's Backup Plus Portable Drive, which backs up photos and videos from Facebook and Flickr.

headline: Tens of Thousands in Athens Protest Cuts
summary: Clashes broke out at an Athens protest as tens of thousands of demonstrators marched through the city in opposition to a fresh round of expected budget cuts from the Greek government.

headline: Japan Opposition Taps Ex-Premier
summary: Japan's main opposition party elected former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe as its new leader, in a turn of events likely to strengthen calls for a hard line against China.

headline: Why Some CEOs Fear Twitter
summary: CEOs are under pressure to appear accessible and "authentic," but social media, with its demands for quick, unscripted updates that can quickly go viral, poses risks for the executives and their firms.

headline: Rajoy Outlines Fresh Overhauls
summary: Spain will restrict programs that make it possible for people to take early retirement as part of overhauls to curb debt, the prime minister said in an interview with the Journal.

headline: A Personal Tribute to Patrick Sandeman
summary: Will Lyons pays tribute to leading British wine merchant Patrick Sandeman, who died last weekend in a sky-diving accident.

headline: American Greetings Family Offers to Buy Company
summary: American Greetings Corp. said the controlling family, led by the CEO, wants to buy the company and take it private in a deal that values the greeting-card maker at about $581 million.

headline: 'Moon River' Crooner Andy Williams Dies
summary: Andy Williams was one of the most distinctive and enduring of the classic croooners, with a career that stretched from radio in the 1940s to recent years, when he performed at his theater in Branson, Mo.

headline: Ending 'Jerky Shame' With Gourmet Flavors
summary: Beef jerky wants to be your healthy snack. Companies are racking up steep sales gains for moister, tastier and fancier dried-meat products made for consumers craving protein.

headline: How Biased Is Your Announcer?
summary: The conventional wisdom in sports is that TV announcers should strive to call the game straight down the middle. Chicago White Sox announcer Ken "Hawk" Harrelson has taken a decidedly different approach.

headline: Spain's IBEX Falls 3.9%
summary: European stocks retreated, led by 3.9% drop in Spain's stock index as its bond yields surged back above 6%.

headline: A Battle Brews Over Coastal Infrastructure
summary: A California agency wants sewage plants and other facilities relocated from the ocean's threat, but cities say it costs too much and delays upgrades.

headline: In California, Reconsidering Waterfront Facilities
summary: California's Pacific coast is dotted with aging sewage plants and other infrastructure that towns are trying to upgrade.

headline: Mitsubishi UFJ Lease in Talks for Jackson Square Aviation
summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Lease & Finance is in final talks to buy Jackson Square Aviation, an aircraft-leasing company, for about $1.29 billion.

headline: The Mitt Whitman Campaign
summary: By Matthew Kaminski  The Romney presidential campaign elicits uncanny—for Republicans, unnerving—parallels to the last gubernatorial election in California.

headline: In Search of the Perfect Roast
summary: A niche of foodies in the Bay Area are turning their kitchens or backyards into do-it-yourself coffee-roasting laboratories in search of the sublime cup of joe.

headline: Chris Murphy's 'I Forgot' Defense
summary: The Senate race in Connecticut keeps getting curiouser and curiouser.

headline: The $4,520 President
summary: By Stephen Moore  Now for the latest bad news on the economy: Median household income is down $4,520 since Barack Obama was inaugurated.

headline: Ousted South African Leader in Court
summary: South African politician Julius Malema, who is leading a push to dislodge Jacob Zuma from the presidency, was charged with money laundering and released on bail.

headline: Inuits Seek to Attract Arctic Mining Investment
summary: A Native American group from Canada's far north is hitting Wall Street Thursday to attract mining investment in a mainly unexplored and potentially lucrative territory: the Arctic.

headline: Dispute Tests Japanese Brands
summary: An island dispute is hitting Japanese businesses in China, the latest test for a commercial relationship that has bounced back from past diplomatic flare-ups.

headline: Roger Bate: India Courts Drug Disaster
summary: Judges setting price caps is the latest ill to befall the pharmaceutical industry.

headline: Sternberg: Staring Down the Paper Dragon
summary: Asia can afford to worry (a little) less about economic reprisals from China.

headline: Germany Still Outperforming Most of Euro Zone
summary: Germany's economy seems set to perform more strongly than most other euro-zone members, with data showing that Italians cut their spending in stores and unemployment fears in France made consumers there less confident.

headline: Hong Kong to Appoint Securities Regulator Chairman
summary: Hong Kong's government will appoint former KPMG executive Carlson Tong chairman of the Securities and Futures Commission.

headline: The Emerging Threat to Oil Prices
summary: Despite America's economic malaise, oil prices have rebounded since 2009 on demand from China and elsewhere. But what comes next—call it recoupling—presents a big risk of its own.

headline: Facebook's Next Fight: Suits, and More Suits
summary: Facebook's botched initial public offering is turning into a potential legal morass for the social-networking firm and its investment bankers.

headline: Car Maker BYD Faces Skeptics
summary: BYD is facing questions about its future as investors grow increasingly skeptical about prospects for the Chinese auto maker's core businesses.

headline: EU Urges Action to Fix Debt Woes
summary: The European Commission distanced itself from a German, Finnish and Dutch statement that appeared to dash hopes that the euro zone's bailout fund could directly recapitalize troubled banks.

headline: Healthful Retreat in Seattle
summary: This 1920s home in Seattle has been in the care of several physicians over the years, one of whom believed in the therapeutic power of 'sleeping porches.'
